page.title: 07Farming-Comm.-Balhalgardy
page.content: East Balhalgardy is situated about 2 kilometres to the north of Inverurie. Its name means "Place of the Priests" as long ago a hospice run by priests was to be found there. The farm is a commercial farm of 540 acres. The farmer Mr Maitland has 275 cattle which are pure Aberdeen Angus. He has Aberdeen Angus calves sent up from Somerset. When they have been fattened he sells them to MacIntosh's slaughterhouse in Inverurie or to the slaughterhouse in Banff. Mr Maitland also has one stock bull, but uses mostly artificial insemination when breeding from his own herd. There are also 70 sheep at East Balhalgardy. The crops grown on Balhalgardy include oats, turnips, peas, oil seed rape, barley and wheat. Most of the turnips are used as winter fodder for the cattle, the rest is sold.
